Pic 3States of MatterMatter exists in three states- solid, liquid and gas. Matter is made up of tiny 
particles called molecules. The arrangement of molecules is different in each state.
12
3Solid– In solids, the molecules are tightly 
packed. They cannot move freely. So, solids 
have a fixed shape and volume. Example 
are– books, tables, beds, buckets and doors 
etc.
We use different type of things in our daily life- books, table, chairs, fans, bags, 
water and many others. There is air around us, though we cannot see it. All 
these things occupy space and have weight. Anything that occupies space and 
has weight is called matter. 
StarterKnow About MatterUnit–VI : The World of Things16Environmental Studies-4119Molecules in solids

Liquid– In liquids, molecules are loosely packed. 
They can move to some distances. So, liquids 
have a fixed volume but do not have a fixed 
shape. They take the shape of the container in 
which they are kept. Water, milk, oil, cold drink 
are some examples of liquids.
Gases– In gases, molecules are very loosely 
packed. They can move freely in all directions. 
So, gases do not have a fixed volume or shape. 
They take the volume and the shape of the 
container. The molecules of the gas spread out 
to take up all the available space. 
Change of StateMatter exists in more than one state. 
water can exist in all three 
For example– 
states– solid, liquid and gas. Matter can be changed from one state to another by 
heating or cooling. 
! Solid to liquid– When we heat a solid, it changes into a liquid. For example, ice 
(solid) changes into water (liquid) on heating. This process is called melting.
! Liquid to gas– When we heat a liquid, it changes into a gas. For example, 
water(liquid) changes into water vapour (gas) on heating. This process is 
called evaporation.
! Gas to liquid– When we cool a gas, it changes into a liquid. For example, water 
vapour (gas) changes into water(liquid) on cooling. This process is called 
condensation.
! Liquid to solid– When we cool a liquid, it changes into a solid. For example, 
water (liquid) changes into ice(solid) on cooling. This process is called 
freezing.
Environmental Studies-4120Molecules in liquidsMolecules in gases

Soluble and Insoluble SubstancesSubstances such as salt and sugar dissolve in water. They are called soluble 
substances. Substances such as wood, sand and chalk do not dissolve in water. 
They are called insoluble substances. A solid that dissolves in a liquid is called 
solute. A liquid in which the solute dissolves is cause a solvent. The liquid we get 
when a solute dissolves in a solvent is called solution.
Solute +Solvent 
SolutionSugar+WaterSugar SolutionTake a glass of water. Add one teaspoon of salt in it. Stir it well what do you 
see? 
You will not be able to see the salt. Taste the water. It tastes salty. Why?
Because, salt has dissolved in water. 
Conclusion– Salt is soluble in water. 
ActivityActivityMiscible and Immiscible LiquidActivity– Take a glass half filled with water. Now at some milk into it. Stir well. The 
two liquids mix together and appear as one liquid. We say that these two liquids 
have dissolved in each other. The liquids which dissolve in each other are called 
miscible liquids. 
Water is called a universal solvent because it can dissolve a 
wide variety of substances.
You 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)WaterAdding SaltSalt solutionEnvironmental Studies-4121Salt

Now, take another glass half filled with water and add 1 teaspoon of some oil in it. 
Stir well. You will see that oil forms a separate layer on top. This shows that these 
two liquid do not dissolve in each other. The liquids which do not dissolve in each 
other are called immiscible liquids. 
Permanent and Temporary ChangesPermanent changes are the changes which remain for a longer time. They are not 
reversible. 
 When we are grown we can't change back into a baby. 
For example–
Thus, growth is a permanent change. 
Some more examples of permanent changes are–
! Milk changing into curd.
! Cooking of rice.
! Burning of coal.
! A baby plant growing into a tree. 
Temporary changes are the changes which are there only for a short period of 
time. Temporary changes are reversible. For example- Water turning into ice is 
WaterAdding milkMiscible liquidsWaterAdding oilImmiscible liquidsEnvironmental Studies-4122Milkoil

called a temporary change because on melting it we can get water again.
Some more examples of temporary changes are–
! Stretching of a spring.
! Folding of a paper sheet.
! Squeezing of a rubber ball.
! Dissolving sugar into water.

Let’s KNOWLet’s KNOWStarterMeasurementUnit–VI : The World of Things17
! What is the tailor doing in Pic 1?
! What is the man doing in Pic 2?
We need to measure a lot of things in our day- to- day life. We measure 
length, distance, weight, time, etc. Some common measurement that we see 
around us are—
Ÿ A vegetable vendor weighs the vegetables which one buys.
Ÿ A tailor stitches our clothes according to our measurement.
Ÿ A cloth merchant measures the length of each piece of cloth which we 
buy.
a tailor measuring lengthof a boy's jeans.
a grocer weighing vegetablewith a beam balanceMeasurementMeasurement is a system to measure the height, weight, capacity, etc. It is done by 
comparing an unknown quantity with a known quantity. This known quantity is 
Environmental Studies-4127

Measurement of LengthLength tells us how long or how tall a thing is. Earlier, people used their body parts 
to measure length. Hand span, cubit and foot span are some units used at that 
time. But, these are non- standard units and the measurement done using body 
parts varies from person to person.
For example— The length measured using your foot span will be different from 
your father's footspan.
called the standard unit.
In this chapter, we will study about the measurement of length, mass and time. 
Hand spanCubitFoot spanNow a days, standard units are used to measure length. The standard unit of length 
is metre (m). Smaller lengths are measured in centimetres (cm) or millimetres 
(mm). Larger lengths are measured in kilometres(km).
Length is measured by using ruler, metre rod or measuring tape. 
The units of length are related to one another.
 
10 millimetres = 
1 centimetre
 
100 centimetres = 
1 metre
 
1000 metres = 
1 kilometre 
RulerRodTapeEnvironmental Studies-4128

Precautions to be taken while using a ruler—
 
1. 
Ruler should be placed very close to the object along its length.
 
2. 
Eye should be kept exactly above the point where the measurement is 
to be taken.
 
3. 
Avoid taking readings from the zero mark of the ruler if its edges are 
broken.
Measurement of MassMass is the measurement of how heavy or light a thing is. Different things have 
different masses. Mass is measured in terms of the weight of the things. Weight of 
lighter things is measured in gram (g) or milligram (mg). Weight of heavier things is 
measured in kilograms (kg).
Weight is measured by using a beam balance or an electronic balance. 
Measure the length of your EVS book 
using a ruler and write the answer in 
the blanks space.

cm long.

100 milligrams =

between two events, Time is 
measured in units called seconds(sec.), 
minutes(min) and hours(hr).
Watches and clocks are used to 
measure time.
Wrist watchWall clockUnits of time are related to one another as—
 
60 seconds = 
1 minute
 
60 minutes = 
1 hourHow to see time in an analogue clock–
 
1. 
Look at the numbers on the clock face.
 
2. 
Locate the shorter hand, which tells you the hour.
 
3. 
Locate the longer hand, which tells you the minutes.
 
4. 
Now, read the time. 
Digital clocka digital clock is an alternative to a traditional 
analogue clock. This type of clock shows 
numbers to display the time in a digital format. 
Analogue watchEnvironmental Studies-4130

Ÿ Hand-Span 
– The maximum distance between the tips of the thumb and 
the little finger.
Ÿ Cubit 
 
– Distance from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger.
Ÿ Foot-Span 
– The distance between the tip of the toe and the heel of the 
foot.

Mapping the NeighbourhoodUnit–VI : The World of Things18
! Rohan's school is near a Police station.
! Rohan’s house is near _________ .
Environmental Studies-4135Rohan's HouseRohan's SchoolShivnagarShivnagarBus StandParkMarketChamunda Devi TempleTanda Medical CollegeStarter

Let’s KNOWLet’s KNOWKnowing the sides—A very simple way of locating a 
place is by knowing the side on which it is situated. 
When we give directions to a place in general manner, 
we use the four sides in relation to our body. The side 
we face is our front, the side behind us is our back, the 
side towards our right hand is the right hand side and 
the side towards our left hand is the left hand side.
Directions— There are four main 
directions east, west, north and south. If 
we stand facing the rising sun, the east is 
in front of us. West is at our back, the left 
hand points towards the north and the 
right hand points towards the south.
Land marks— Landmarks are important points or places of reference which help 
us to locate a place where we have to reach. A cinema hall, hospital, school, 
temple, market or even a pole or tree are some landmarks which can be easily 
identified in a locality.
Sketches— A sketch is rough drawing of a place which helps us to locate our 
destination. It does not show the exact distance of one place in relation to another 
place.
Maps—A map is a flat drawing of place . Unlike a sketch, a map shows directions. A 
map contains signs, symbols and a scale to locate the place shown on it.
Directions, landmarks, sketches, maps etc. help us to locate a place where 
we have to reach. They guide our movements better and reduce the time 
and efforts required to reach our destination. They also prevent us from 
getting lost.
Environmental Studies-4136

Colours– On a map different colours are used to represent different land forms and 
water bodies. Some of them are–
 1. Blue colour 
— 
river, oceans, seas etc
 2. Yellow colour 
— 
deserts
 3. Green colour 
— 
plains
 4. Brown colour 
— 
mountains
 5. Red colour 
— 
plateau
 6. White colour 
— 
snowSigns and Symbols– Signs and symbols are used to show features like rivers, roads, 
temples, bridges, dams, railways etc on a map.
 Some of them are–
 Railway 
 
 
 
 
 
Bridge
 Gurudwars 
 
 
 
 
 
Dam
 Temple 
 
 
 
 
 
Forest
 Church 
 
 
 
 
 
Post office
 Mosque 
 
 
 
 
 
Police station
 Metalled Road 
 
 
 
 
Unmetalled roadScale of map– A map is much smaller than the area shown by it. So a scale has to be 
used to draw a map. A scale uses a small unit of measurement which is equal to 
much bigger unit.
For example – if 1 cm = 100 km,
On the map, the distance between two places A and B is 2 cm. Then, they are 200 
km away from each other, on the ground. A scale is always given in a corner of the 
map. A book containing different maps is called an Atlas.
Direction on the map– The top side of the map always shows north, bottom side 
shows south, left hand side shows west and the right hand side shows east. All the 
maps contain this pattern of direction.
Features of a MapEnvironmental Studies-4137

You 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)
! 
Destination 
– The place where we have to reach.
! 
Metalled Road 
– Roads made up of cement, concrete and coal tar.
! 
Unmetalled Roads 
– Roads made up of mud and gravel (generally 
found in rural areas).
! 
Legend 
– The explanation of colours, sign and symbols in a 
map.
Legend or key– A legend or key tells us what the 
colours and the symbols used in the map 
represent. It is usually given in a small box in the 
corner of the map.
How to draw a map– To draw the map of a place, we need to keep the landmarks of 
that place in mind. Now, first take a centre point. Then go right from it and keep 
drawing the landmarks you find. Similarly go up, down and left. Use symbols to 
show each place that you see. Then draw a legend to explain the symbols you have 
used in your map.
We should learn how to read a map as it is an important skill. It helps us to find our 
way and to stay safe.
The art of making maps is called cartography and the people who make 
maps are called cartographers.
Key termsKey termsKey termsYou 
 KnowMust 
(Knowledge)Nowadays people use digital maps and can share their exact location 
through their devices.
Environmental Studies-4138
